questions.question: What does 'c' represent in the M/G/c/N queueing system?

answers.b: Number of servers in the system
answers.c: Maximum number of customers allowed in the system

explanations.a: Incorrect. 'c' does not represent the arrival rate of customers.
explanations.b: Incorrect. 'c' does not represent the number of servers in the system.
explanations.c: Correct. 'c' represents the maximum number of customers allowed in the system in an M/G/c/N queueing model.
explanations.d: Incorrect. 'c' does not represent the service rate of the server.

questions.question: How does the M/G/c/N model differ from the M/M/c/N model?

answers.a: The service process in M/G/c/N has general distribution, while it's exponential service process in M/M/c/N.
answers.b: Both models use the same service distribution.
answers.c: M/G/c/N model allows for a finite capacity, while M/M/c/N model has infinite capacity.
answers.d: M/G/c/N model has a deterministic arrival pattern, while M/M/c/N model has a random arrival pattern.

explanations.a: Correct. The M/G/c/N model assumes general distribution for service, while the M/M/c/N model assumes an exponential service process.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The service distribution may differ between the two models.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Both models allow for finite capacity, but the nature of the arrival process differs.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Both models may have random arrival patterns, but the service time distributions differ.

questions.question: What happens in an M/G/c/N queue when the number of customers exceeds 'N'?

answers.a: Additional servers are added to handle the overflow.
answers.c: New arrivals are rejected, resulting in system overflow.
answers.d: The service rate increases to accommodate the excess customers.

explanations.a: Incorrect. Additional servers are not typically added in an M/G/c/N queueing system.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Excess customers are not served immediately in a finite capacity queue.
explanations.c: Correct. When the number of customers exceeds 'N', new arrivals are rejected, leading to system overflow.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The service rate does not increase in response to exceeding the system capacity.

questions.question: How does the utilization factor 'ρ' affect the performance of an M/G/c/N queue?

answers.a: Higher ρ leads to lower average waiting times.
answers.b: Lower ρ leads to higher system stability.
answers.c: ρ does not affect the performance of the system.
answers.d: Higher ρ leads to higher probabilities of queue overflow.

explanations.a: Incorrect. Higher utilization factor ('ρ') leads to higher average waiting times.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Lower utilization factor ('ρ') generally leads to higher system stability.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Utilization factor ('ρ') significantly affects the performance of the system.
explanations.d: Correct. Higher utilization factor ('ρ') leads to higher probabilities of queue overflow and poorer system performance.
